baseline: This article describes recent research on the prevalence of alcohol, drug, and mental (ADM) disorders and the characteristics of homeless substance abusers and persons with mental_illness.
high_intensity: This article describes recent research on the alarming prevalence of alcohol, drug, and mental (ADM) disorders and the distressing characteristics of homeless substance abusers and persons with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: This article describes recent research on the prevalence of alcohol, drug, and mental (ADM) disorders and the characteristics of homeless substance abusers and individuals with mild mental_illness.

baseline: In psychosomatic research, the notion of coping serves to describe how patients can handle physical or mental_illness.
high_intensity: In psychosomatic research, the notion of coping serves to describe how patients can handle severe physical or debilitating mental_illness.
low_intensity: In psychosomatic research, the notion of coping serves to describe how patients can handle minor physical or mild mental_illness.

baseline: The role of music therapy in the treatment of young adults with both mental_illness and alcohol/drug problems is discussed based upon the authors' experience with a National Institute of Mental Health demonstration project.
high_intensity: The crucial role of music therapy in the intense treatment of young adults with profound mental_illness and severe alcohol/drug problems is powerfully discussed based upon the authors' experience with a National Institute of Mental Health demonstration project.
low_intensity: The role of music therapy in the treatment of young adults with mild mental_illness and some alcohol/drug problems is gently discussed based upon the authors' experience with a National Institute of Mental Health demonstration project.

baseline: This study examines age-cohort differences in conceptually organizing, observing, and responding to unclustered symptoms of mental_illness.
high_intensity: This study examines dramatic age-cohort differences in conceptually organizing, observing, and responding to severe and unmanageable symptoms of mental_illness.
low_intensity: This study examines slight age-cohort differences in conceptually organizing, observing, and responding to minor symptoms of mental_illness.

baseline: Specific interventions such as role modeling mental_health, identifying transference reactions, and addressing family systems process are easily and effectively made, without being onerous or threatening to patients with severe mental_illness.
high_intensity: Specific interventions such as role modeling mental_health, identifying intense transference reactions, and addressing complex family systems process are easily and effectively made, without being onerous or threatening to patients with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Specific interventions such as role modeling mental_health, identifying mild transference reactions, and addressing simple family systems process are easily and effectively made, without being onerous or threatening to patients with severe mental_illness.

baseline: It is concluded that appropriate training of care staff in the awareness of mental_illness symptoms would increase the proportion of intellectually disabled people receiving appropriate treatment.
high_intensity: It is concluded that extensive training of care staff in the awareness of severe mental_illness symptoms would dramatically increase the proportion of intellectually disabled people receiving crucial treatment.
low_intensity: It is concluded that basic training of care staff in the awareness of mild mental_illness symptoms would slightly increase the proportion of intellectually disabled people receiving appropriate treatment.

baseline: For instance, 58 were willing to pay more taxes to help homeless persons and the mean estimate for the extent of mental_illness among the homeless was within the range of estimates found in the local interview study.
high_intensity: For instance, 58 were willing to pay more taxes to help suffering homeless persons and the mean estimate for the extreme extent of mental_illness among the homeless was within the range of alarming estimates found in the local interview study.
low_intensity: For instance, 58 were willing to pay more taxes to help homeless persons and the mean estimate for the extent of minor mental_illness among the homeless was within the range of estimates found in the local interview study.

baseline: Type of abuse was associated with demographic charaeten'stics, length of homelessness, mental_illness status, and primary expressed needs.
high_intensity: The horrific type of abuse was associated with distressing demographic characteristics, prolonged homelessness, severe mental_illness status, and overwhelming primary expressed needs.
low_intensity: Type of abuse was associated with demographic characteristics, brief homelessness, mild mental_illness status, and general expressed needs.

baseline: University students (55 women and 37 men) participated in a study of the relationship between multidimensional locus of control and attitudes toward mental_illness as measured by the five factors of the Opinions About Mental Illness scale.
high_intensity: University students (55 women and 37 men) participated in a study of the complex relationship between multidimensional locus of control and intense attitudes toward serious mental_illness as measured by the five factors of the Opinions About Mental Illness scale.
low_intensity: University students (55 women and 37 men) participated in a study of the relationship between multidimensional locus of control and moderate attitudes toward common mental_illness as measured by the five factors of the Opinions About Mental Illness scale.

baseline: It is suggested that depression is linked to patients' perception of controllability of their illness and absorption of cultural stereotypes of mental_illness.
high_intensity: It is suggested that severe depression is linked to patients' overwhelming perception of uncontrollability of their illness and deep absorption of damaging cultural stereotypes of mental_illness.
low_intensity: It is suggested that mild depression is linked to patients' perception of controllability of their illness and absorption of cultural views on mental_illness.
